titleStmt.title: A new petition: earnestly entreating subscription of hands to back the late city remonstrance. Unto which is annexed a usefull dialogue, betwixt a church-warden and a parishioner, declaring the danger of the said new petition. Serving as a Christian caveat to the wise-hearted, to take heed of having their feet taken in the snare thereof. / By a cordiall wel-willer to the peace of this famous city. Licensed and entred according to order.
titleStmt.author: Cordiall Wel-Willer to the Peace of This Famous City.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

figure.head: York
figure.p: Pack up and away from Oxford.

div.p: A NEW PETITION: Earne≈øtly entreating Sub≈øcription of Hands to back the late City Remon≈øtrance.
Unto which is annexed a u≈øefull Dialogue, betwixt a Church-warden and a Pari≈øhioner, Declaring the danger of the ≈øaid NEW PETITION.
Serving as a Chri≈øtian Caveat to the wi≈øe-hearted, to take heed of having their feet taken in the ≈ønare thereof.
By a cordiall Wel-willer to the peace of this famous City.

p.hi: Licen≈øed and Entred according to Order.

div.head: A New Petition, earne≈øtly entreating Sub≈øcription of Hands.
To the Right Honourable the Lord Major, the Aldermen and Commons of the City of London in Common Councell A≈ø≈øembled.
The humble Petition of divers well-affected Citizens and Free-men of London under the jurisdiction of the Lord Major.
div.p:
THat the great care and unce≈ø≈øant paines of this Honourable Court for the promoting of the cau≈øe of God, is ≈øo eminently knowne, that your Petitioners cunceive that they ≈øhall be too much wanting to their owne duties and ≈øafety if they ≈øhould bee backward in the thankfull acknowledgement thereof. Wherefore as they give you many humble and hearty thanks for what you have already done in reference to the publike good, ≈øo being de≈øirous in what in them lyes yet further to ≈øtrengthen your hands to ≈øo glorious a worke they cannot but let you know their re≈øolutions to adhere unto you in all your ju≈øt and legall proceedings, not doubting but the ≈øame good hand of God that hath hitherto been with you will ≈øtill bee upon you for good, whil≈øt you endeavour in your places the e≈øtabli≈øhment of truth & peace, & the removing tho≈øe pre≈ø≈øing grievances, that lye upon us as you have lately done in that free & nece≈ø≈øary, yet
humble and dutifull Remon≈øtrance & Petition unto the Honourable Hou≈øes of Parliament, and however there wants not tho≈øe for the pre≈øent, who out of ≈øelf-re≈øpects calumniate your good intention therein, yet being per≈øwaded that in very faithfulne≈ø≈øe to the publike you have done it, your Petitioners not only approve of it but rejoyce in it, the rather ≈øince they know no other ordinary way for obtaining remedy for their common grievances then by your addre≈ø≈øes to the Parliament in their behalf.

Your Petitioners therfore humbly Pray, that this Honorable Court would be plea≈øed ≈øtill to per≈øevere and couragiou≈øly goe on, and by all pious and prudent meanes endeavouring the ≈øpeedy ≈øettlement of Religion, the Peace of the Kingdome, the union of both Nations, the ≈øafety and welfare of this City, and in a word the performance of the Covenant,, wherein we are Solemnly engaged unto God the righteous Judge of all the world: In reference unto all which good ends your Petitioners pray, that you would ≈øtill continue your humble addre≈ø≈øes unto the Parliament, not onely for a gracious An≈øwer of your ≈øaid late Remon≈øtrance, but for all ≈øuch other things as ≈øhall nece≈ø≈øary conduce to the putting a happy period to our pre≈øent mi≈øerable di≈øtractions; and that the meane time you would put in execution among≈øt your ≈øelves ≈øo many branches thereof as the power wherewith (by the Lawes of this Kingdome, you are already inve≈øted) will extend unto.

div.head: Ob≈øervations upon the fore going Petition by way of Dialogue between a Church-warden and a Pari≈øhioner.

sp.speaker: Church-warden.
sp.p: COme Neighbour, here is a very ≈øober, moderate, and pious Petition, tending much for the glorie of God, the peace of the kingdome, and the common good; will you ≈øub≈øcribe it?

sp.speaker: Pari≈øhioner.
sp.p: Sir, I de≈øire to be excu≈øed: for my part I doe not like it.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: Not like it man? what hone≈øt man can di≈ølike it?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Sir, It is a very dangerous Petition, and there is more mi≈øchiefe coucht in it then you are aware of.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: I thinke in my con≈øcience ≈øome men will finde fault with any thing; why man it is as harmle≈ø≈øe a Petition as ever was ≈øub≈øcribed unto; and many hone≈øt, and under≈øtanding men have ≈øub≈øcribed it.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: I will not make other mens examples, but mine owne Rea≈øon, the Rule of my actions: hone≈øt men may ≈øometimes do knaves worke, & the mo≈øt cunning ≈øtraines of de≈øtperate Malignancy; and dangerous con≈øequence are alwaies carried on by abu≈øed ≈øimplicity, but I look upon it as a very dangerous Petition

sp.speaker: Chur.
sp.p: I know you are none of the≈øe Shimaticall Sectaries, which have ever beene the unhappie di≈øturbers of the publike peace of Church and ≈øtate; who≈øe totall ≈øuppre≈ø≈øion would bee a happie thing to this land and nation, I pray you tell mee the rea≈øon why you will not ≈øub≈øcibe it, I'le a≈ø≈øure you wee are to returne the names of tho≈øe that deny ≈øub≈øcription.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Returne the names, to whom? have you any authority that put you on worke? for my part I was never known to contemne thority; tell me to whom mu≈øt you returne the names of the non-≈øub≈øcribers.

sp.speaker: Chur.
sp.p: Excu≈øe me there, I ≈øpeake as your friend, and in my love to you, but I pray you take no notice of that, but tell me the rea≈øon why you will not ≈øub≈øcribe it.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Why I'le tell you, fir≈øt I like not the thing in the generall. 2. I like not ≈øome things more particular?

sp.speaker: Ch:
sp.p: What doe you di≈ø-like in it in the generall.

sp.speaker: Par:
sp.p: Why truly in the generall I look upon it as meer ≈øeditition, and that which hath a very dangerous tendency in it, and may likely prove an utter breach between Citie and Pariiament, and confident I am (however you are abu≈øed) clo≈øe malignancy lies at the root, and if my councell be worthy to be taken, have no further hand in it.

sp.speaker: Ch:
sp.p: Sedition man? how can that be, I am ≈øure as hone≈øt men, and as good friends to the Parliament as any are in this Citie (none excepted) have their hands in it.

sp.speaker: Par:
sp.p: It's no matter for that, hone≈øt men are not in all things the mo≈øt politiek, I'le give you an account of my thoughts of it.

sp.speaker: Ch:
sp.p: Truly I have alwayes taken you for an under≈øtanding man, not ra≈øh, but rationall, tell me why do you think it ≈øedition?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Why I'le tell you, the City hath petitioned and Remon≈øtrated to the Hou≈øe, the Hou≈øe ≈øhew no te≈øtimonie of their acceptance (but rather their di≈ølike) of it, if in ≈øuch a Ca≈øe a party ≈øhall joyne together, and ≈øub≈øcribe a re≈øolutution to ≈øticke unto tho≈øe, and promi≈øe to backe them in any thing whereto the Parliament ≈øhows their di≈ølike, it is ab≈øolute in my judgement ≈øedition, and a direct faction, and that which tends to make a very heavy breach between the Citie and Parliament: for it is no le≈øs then to rai≈øe up a party again≈øt the Parliament.

sp.speaker: Ch:
sp.p: I confe≈ø≈øe there may be more in it then I ≈øee before: but confident I am, that there are many hone≈øt men that would cut off their hands before they would ≈øub≈øcribe it, if they thought ≈øo?

sp.speaker: Par:
sp.p: I do beleeve ≈øo too; but I verily think the de≈øigne is deeper then you are aware of, and I partly perceive whence it comes about, that there are ≈øuch daily tamperings with Citizens in matters of this nature?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: I pray you tell me your thoughts freely.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
Why, I'le tell you, many Malignants are come into the City, and have made their peace with the Parliament by their Compo≈øitions; though they are as directly Royalli≈øts as ever they were: moreover, many Malignant Epi≈øcopall Prie≈øts are likewi≈øe by Compo≈øitions admitted into the City, both the one and the other, having cunning heads, choi≈øe wits, deep reaches, and malignant hearts, having ≈øome hopes that the Scots and the King will joyne together again≈øt the Parliament: (though
for my part I have ≈øtrong confidence (what ever the Kings de≈øign may be) the Scots will appeare hone≈øt) the≈øe men well knowing that if they could but divide London from the Parliament, and get tho≈øe men ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed that have done them as much mi≈øchiefe as any in the Kingdome under the notion of Schi≈ømaticks, Annabapti≈øts, Independants and Sectaries, the≈øe men (I ≈øay may foment divi≈øions between the well-affected, and the City and Parliament, not doubting but (if that was once irreconcileably done, what with the Scots, the Kings Party in the Kingdome & Citie) the game would goe on their ≈øides, and ≈øo they have their de≈øires; Againe we have a great many Mini≈øters here, in and about the Citie, ≈øome whereof doubtle≈ø≈øe in con≈øcience to the glory of God, being much affected with the divi≈øions and errours of the Times, others bya≈ø≈øed with ba≈øe ends of honour, and profit, the≈øe by their invective preachings, ≈øtirring up the Magi≈øtrates in their more popular Sermons at We≈øtmin≈øter, Pauls, every morning exerci≈øe in the Citie: as al≈øo by their bitter writings again≈øt tho≈øe that agree not with them in Church government? and their di≈øper≈øions of their unchri≈øtian like bookes abroad, ≈øuch as Ma≈øter Edwards bookes are (enough to ≈øet a whole Kingdome on fire) as al≈øo by the methods that are contriv'd by ≈øome, ≈øending abroad, and ≈øpreading their in≈øtructions, directions, & advice for the preaching on ≈øuch ≈øubjects throughout the Citie and Kingdome as people are not able to bear; whereby divi≈øions, wrath, di≈øcord, and generall di≈øcontents are fomented throughout the Kingdome, ≈øetting Meni≈øter again≈øt people, and people again≈øt Mini≈øter, ≈øtirring up and provoking the City to be trouble≈øome to the Parliament, to petition againe and again, under a pretence of zeal for the hou≈øe of God, the glory of God, the reformation of the Kingdome, the ≈øetting up (and that with a rigorous exaction of uniformity therein) of that governement wherein indeed them≈øelves do not agree, ≈øome holding it Jure Divino, others Jure Humano, and ≈øo they make a great bu≈øling in the Citie and Kingdome about they know not what: hereupon it is very probable, for I ≈øpeake my thoughts, they ≈øtirre up the people to joyne with the Common Councell, and to ≈øtick unto them, in≈øinuating that the Parliament can do nothing without the Citie, and therefore petition: and if that will not do, petition, and if that will not doe, petition againe and againe untill
they doe an≈øwer you, and that to your content: for doubtle≈ø≈øe if they ≈øee you are many in number, and re≈øolved in the thing, they mu≈øt not deny you, &c. This is another cau≈øe of the≈øe kind of procceedings, I blunder out my own opinion, you know I am plain, the≈øe I profe≈ø≈øe are my very thoughts? and for my part I look upon this very Petition as widening the di≈øtance, and encrea≈øing the fire, and enlarging divi≈øions, and therefore beleeve it I ≈øhall have no hand in it; it grieves me to ≈øee how ≈øimply men are hurried on to their own dammage, let the Parliament alone and God ble≈ø≈øe them, and let the City act within its ≈øpheare, and every of us ≈øtudy more peace and love and Chri≈øtian ≈øweetene≈ø≈øe in our carriages one towards another then we do. This for the generall:

sp.speaker: Ch:
sp.p: What are your particular exceptions again≈øt it?

sp.speaker: Par:
sp.p: Truly I cannot ≈øtand now to examine all things in it, but I ≈øhall only for pre≈øent upon a ≈øuddain let you know my exceptions again≈øt one thing you ≈øpake of in the prayer, you petition the Lord Major and Common Councell, as they make con≈øcience of their ≈øolemn Leagus and Covenant, that they endeavour the ≈øettlement of Religion, I concceive you mean Pre≈øbiteriall Government, do you not?

sp.speaker: Ch:
sp.p: Yes doubtle≈ø≈øe we mean nothing el≈øe, for that we ≈øuppo≈øe to be according to the Word of God, and the be≈øt Reformed Churches?

sp.speaker: Par:
sp.p: Why then by this kind of interpretation every man is bound to ≈øtrive to compell others to conformity unto that Government, which hee ≈øuppo≈øeth to be according to the Word of God, and the example of the be≈øt Reformed Churches: ≈øo the Anabapti≈øt he is bound to compell others to his judgement: Independants to do the like, ≈øeekers to do the like, and ≈øo this kind of expo≈øition of the Covenant, puts a ≈øword into the hands of all ≈øorts of Sectaries, and people of different judgments to rend and teare and devour one another, and what a dividing and dangerous interpretation of the Covenant is this? to pre≈ø≈øe men as they tender a good con≈øcience to ruine one another. Sir, I am a little in ha≈øt, I have told you my pre≈øent thoughts in ≈øhort: I cannot ≈øub≈øcribe the Petition.

sp.speaker: Ch:
sp.p: I thank you for your freene≈ø≈øe of di≈øcour≈øe, I promi≈øe you I'le be better advi≈øed before I proced any further therein.
